author: Chinua Achebe
title: Things Fall Apart
description: This novel explores the life of Okonkwo, a respected Igbo leader. It delves into themes of tradition, identity, and change. The story portrays the complexities of pre-colonial society in Nigeria. It highlights the clash between indigenous culture and European colonization. Achebe’s work is a cornerstone of African literature.

author: Hans Christian Andersen
title: Fairy tales
description: A collection of enchanting stories for children and adults alike. Includes well-known tales like 'The Little Mermaid' and 'The Ugly Duckling.' Andersen's works are rich with moral lessons and imagination. They have been translated into numerous languages worldwide. The tales remain timeless classics in literature.

author: Dante Alighieri
title: The Divine Comedy
description: A monumental epic that journeys through Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise. It explores themes of sin, salvation, and divine justice. Written in the vernacular Italian, it revolutionized European literature. Dante’s vivid imagery and symbolism remain influential. A masterpiece of medieval philosophy and theology.

author: Unknown
title: The Epic Of Gilgamesh
description: One of the earliest known works of literature. It follows the adventures of King Gilgamesh. Themes include friendship, mortality, and the search for meaning. The story includes a flood narrative similar to other ancient texts. A cornerstone of Mesopotamian cultural history.

author: Unknown
title: The Book Of Job
description: An ancient Hebrew text that explores the problem of suffering. It tells the story of Job, a man tested by divine trials. Themes include faith, justice, and human resilience. A philosophical and poetic masterpiece of biblical literature. It offers profound insights into the human condition.

author: Unknown
title: One Thousand and One Nights
description: A captivating collection of Middle Eastern folk tales. Framed by the story of Scheherazade, who tells tales to save her life. Themes include adventure, love, betrayal, and magic. Stories like Aladdin and Sinbad are part of this compilation. A treasure trove of timeless narratives.

author: Unknown
title: Njál's Saga
description: A medieval Icelandic saga of family, law, and vengeance. It depicts conflicts over honor, loyalty, and justice. Central to the story is the wise but tragic Njál. The saga reflects the harsh realities of medieval Icelandic society. A key text in Old Norse literature.

author: Jane Austen
title: Pride and Prejudice
description: A beloved novel of manners and romance. It follows Elizabeth Bennet as she navigates love and social expectations. Themes include class, family, and personal growth. Mr. Darcy, a complex romantic hero, is iconic. Austen's wit and social critique shine throughout.

author: Chinua Achebe
title: Things Fall Apart
description: This novel explores the life of Okonkwo, a respected Igbo leader. It delves into themes of tradition, identity, and change. The story portrays the complexities of pre-colonial society in Nigeria. It highlights the clash between indigenous culture and European colonization. Achebe’s work is a cornerstone of African literature.

author: Hans Christian Andersen
title: Fairy tales
description: A collection of enchanting stories for children and adults alike. Includes well-known tales like 'The Little Mermaid' and 'The Ugly Duckling.' Andersen's works are rich with moral lessons and imagination. They have been translated into numerous languages worldwide. The tales remain timeless classics in literature.

author: Dante Alighieri
title: The Divine Comedy
description: A monumental epic that journeys through Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise. It explores themes of sin, salvation, and divine justice. Written in the vernacular Italian, it revolutionized European literature. Dante’s vivid imagery and symbolism remain influential. A masterpiece of medieval philosophy and theology.

author: Unknown
title: The Epic Of Gilgamesh
description: One of the earliest known works of literature. It follows the adventures of King Gilgamesh. Themes include friendship, mortality, and the search for meaning. The story includes a flood narrative similar to other ancient texts. A cornerstone of Mesopotamian cultural history.

title: The Book Of Job
description: An ancient Hebrew text that explores the problem of suffering. It tells the story of Job, a man tested by divine trials. Themes include faith, justice, and human resilience. A philosophical and poetic masterpiece of biblical literature. It offers profound insights into the human condition.

author: Honoré de Balzac
title: Le Père Goriot
description: A realist novel depicting the lives of Parisian society. It examines ambition, sacrifice, and the pursuit of success. The story follows the downfall of Père Goriot, a devoted father. Balzac paints a vivid picture of 19th-century France. Part of his massive series, 'La Comédie Humaine.'

author: William Faulkner
title: Absalom, Absalom!
description: This Southern Gothic novel is a complex narrative of a family's tragic history, exploring the themes of race, family secrets, and the deep-rooted social issues of the South. Faulkner employs a non-linear structure, layering multiple perspectives to reveal the dark past of Thomas Sutpen, a man whose ambition and actions lead to his downfall. The novel is a dense, emotionally charged examination of the South’s history and the ways personal and social tragedies are intertwined.

author: William Faulkner
title: The Sound and the Fury
description: In this landmark modernist novel, Faulkner uses stream-of-consciousness and fragmented time structures to depict the decline of the Compson family in the South. The narrative is divided into four parts, each told from the perspective of different family members. The novel explores themes of memory, loss, and the passage of time, capturing the emotional decay and cultural shifts in the post-Civil War South. 'The Sound and the Fury' is celebrated for its innovative narrative techniques and its poignant exploration of human suffering.

author: Gustave Flaubert
title: Madame Bovary
description: This novel tells the tragic story of Emma Bovary, a young woman who seeks escape from the monotony of provincial life through romance and materialism. Flaubert critiques the limitations of bourgeois society and the consequences of excessive romanticism. The book is notable for its realistic portrayal of life and its focus on the inner turmoil of its central character. 'Madame Bovary' is regarded as one of the finest examples of literary realism and one of Flaubert’s greatest achievements.

author: Gustave Flaubert
title: Sentimental Education
description: Flaubert’s novel is a sweeping coming-of-age story about the disillusionment and romantic failures of the protagonist, Frederic Moreau, in 19th-century France. The novel critiques the social and political structures of the time, as Frederic navigates his desires and ambitions. Flaubert’s precise and elegant prose captures the emotional and intellectual struggles of a generation caught between idealism and reality. It is a key work in the tradition of French realism and modern literature.

author: Federico García Lorca
title: Gypsy Ballads
description: A collection of poems that delve into the soul of Andalusia, combining elements of folklore, myth, and personal expression. García Lorca captures the passions, struggles, and tragedies of the Spanish Romani people through his vivid and evocative language. The work is known for its lyrical beauty and emotional depth, exploring themes of love, death, and social injustice. Lorca’s unique blend of surrealism and traditional Spanish culture makes this collection a powerful exploration of human emotion.
